questiontext.text:
Live data capture

STACK can be used in conjunction with live data capture in science labs.  For example, here is a sample question which confirms if students have calculated a speed correctly from their own data.

Multiple properties

In this question STACK establishes multiple separate properties.  Here they are

  1. Continuous at x=0
  2. Differentiable at x=0
  3. Gradient is zero at x=2.

Typically, the answer to a mathematical question will need a number of separate things, e.g. equivalent to the correct answer, appropriate written form.  The teacher has to decide what these properties are, and design feedback if some, or all, are not satisfied.

The teacher can also choose to test for properties which arise as a result of common misconceptions.

Try (x-2)^2+1

Specific feedback

In this, more advanced, question the student is required to find a cubic polynomial which matches up with the given function f(x).  In particular it should connect smoothly with both given ends.

There are are five separate properties that characterize a correct answer

  1. p(x) is a cubic (the highest power of x is 3).
  2. p(-2)=1 (connects at the left)
  3. p(0)=0 (connects at the right)
  4. p'(-2)=0 (slope is correct at the left)
  5. p'(0)=1 (slope is correct at the right)

In this case there is, up to algebraic equivalence, only one correct answer.  In fact, it is more helpful to students to check each property separately and give more specific feedback.  

Try x^2*(x+3)/4 which is only partially correct.

(The correct answer is x^3/2+7*x^2/4+x)

Entering mathematical expressions into STACK

When you are answering the following questions please enter mathematical expressions in the form that you would enter them into a spreadsheet.

For example what you might write as 5x2 you should type as 5*x^2. You will find that the computer will interpret what you have typed and reflect it back to you in mathematical format.

In practice, students need to learn how to type in their answers, and after a relatively short period the majority are able to do so.

Please try the "syntax quiz" before attempting at this.  The purpose of the syntax quiz is to teach the syntax!

Establishing mathematical properties

STACK uses a computer algebra system to establish the mathematical properties of student's answers.  In some cases this is equivalence (as was the case with the railways question previously).  A much wider range of properties can be established, and in many cases there will be a whole range of acceptable answers which satisfy them.

A function f(x) is even if f(x)=f(-x) for all values of x.  For example, x2, 3cos(x) and x sin(x) are all even.  Try getting these questions wrong!

The teacher always has to specify what properties are relevant to the question.

Modelling

In this question the student is asked to write down a system of equations which represent the situation described.  There are many equivalent ways to do this.  STACK uses computer algebra to check if the student's answer is equivalent to the correct system.  

E.g. try one of the following

v*t=90
(v+5)*(t-1/4)=90

d=90
v*t=d
(v+5)*(t-1/4)=v*t

The system can also check common mistakes (where the teacher knows about them in advance, which is commonly the case).  E.g. forgetting about units of time is relatively common.  Try using 15 minuites instead of 1/4 hour.

v*t=90
(v+5)*(t-15)=v*t

name.text: tangent to a random polynomial at a point_info

questiontext.text:
Randomly generated versions

STACK generates random question versions for each attempt at the quiz.  This is done in a sophisticated mathematical way, not by just putting random numbers into boxes which might lead to impossible questions.

Practice of methods and feedback

This symbolic integration question is typical of many mathematical methods. 

In this case get the question wrong.  E.g. by typing in something like (3*x^2+1)^3+c as an answer.

Feedback is given to students which includes a calculation of the student's answer.  This is designed to help students check their own work, and hence improve on this task.

Multi-part questions

Sometimes, particularly when first learning a topic, it is helpful to students to break a complex question down into parts.  STACK can implement follow-through marking, taking an incorrect answer from the student in the first part and using it in the second.

For example, try typing in the following answers to the first two parts

  1. x+10=56
  2. {46}

(The answer in part (2) needs to be a set which is entered using curly brackets and commas as { ?, ?, ?, ...}.  Here there is one element in the set.).  The system is able to establish that the second answer is correct, given the first one, even though the first answer is incorrect.

In this question use the data captured from your moving cart in the speed lab.  

How far did the cart go? [[input:d]] meters.  [[validation:d]]

How long did it take? [[input:t]] seconds. [[validation:t]]

So what is the speed? [[input:ans1]] m/s. [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: Remember that \[ d=st\].  So if you have a distance of \(d\) meters, in a time of \(s\) seconds, then the speed will be \(s/d\).

falsefeedback.text: The speed you entered is not consistent with the data you entered for the first two parts.
Your answer should simply be a number, representing the final answer.

truefeedback.text: Think carefully about how you calculate your ratio!

questiontext.text:
Give an example of an even function.
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: Remember, a function \(f(x)\) is said to be {\em even} if \[ f(x) = f(-x) \] for all values of \(x\). Hence, there are many examples which satisfy this definition, \(\cos(x)\), \(3*x^4\), and even \(f(x)=c\) for any constant.

questiontext.text:
Find a function of \(f(x)\) which satisfies \[ f(a+b)=f(a)+f(b)\] for all values of \(a\) and \(b\).
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

Give an example of a function \(f(x)\) with a stationary point at \(x={@n@}\) and which is continuous but not differentiable at \(x=0\).

\(f(x)=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

falsefeedback.text: Your answer does not have a stationary point at \(x={@n@}\) but should do.
Your answer is not continuous at \(x=0\), but needs to be.
Your answer is differentiable at \(x=0\) but should not be. Consider using \(|x|\), which is entered as <tt>abs(x)</tt>, somewhere in your answer.

questiontext.text:
Give an example of an odd function.
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: Remember, a function \(f(x)\) is said to be {\em odd} if \[ f(x) = -f(-x) \] for all values of \(x\). Hence, there are many examples which satisfy this definition, \(\sin(x)\), \(4*x^5\), and even \(f(x)=0\).

falsefeedback.text: Your function should have a symmetry in the \(y\) axis, but does not.

questiontext.text:
Give an example of a quadratic with roots at \(x={@n@}\) and \(x={@m@}\).
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

falsefeedback.text: Your answer should be a quadratic but is not.
Your answer should have a root at \(x={@n@}\) but does not.
Your answer should have a root at \(x={@m@}\) but does not.

questiontext.text:
Find a quadratic, \[ x^2 +bx +c, \] other than \(x^2\), which has roots equal to \(b\) and \(c\).
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Since \(b\) and \(c\) are the roots, we have \[ (x-b)(x-c) =0. \] Expanding this, and comparing coefficients, we have that \[ \left. \begin{array}{rcl} b+c = -b \\ bc = c \end{array} \right\} \] From the second of these equations, either \(b=1\) or \(c=0\).
If \(c=0\), the first gives \(b=0\), resulting in \(x^2\).
If \(b=1\), then \(c=-2\), giving only one other solution \[ (x+2)(x-1) = x^2 +x -2.\] (By Teiji Nakazawa, Mathematical Gazette, No. 358, pg 315, 1962)

truefeedback.text: Yes, \(x^2\) is correct, but you need to give another answer!

questiontext.text:
Give an example of a function \(f(x)\) with a stationary point at \(x={@n@}\).
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
In this question you are asked to find a function with the property that there is a stationary point at \(x={@n@}\). That is to say that the gradient here will be zero. There are two main ways to go about this
  • Take a known function and graph shift it to put the stationary point in the correct place.
  • Take a function with a zero in the correct place an integrate it.
There are many different examples.

questiontext.text:
Give an example of a function \(f(x)\) with a stationary point at \(x={@n@}\) and which is continuous but not differentiable at \(x=0\).

\(f(x)=\)[[input:ans1]]

[[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
One way to construct such a function is to start with a continuous curve (the first property) with a stationary point at \(x={@n@}\) and then to "bend" the curve at the point at which we need differentiability to fail.  This can be done using the absolute value function \(|x|\).

We start with a quadratic with roots at \(x=0\) and \(x=2\times {@n@}\) which has a stationary point at the required \(x={@n@}\).  For example \(x(x-{@2*n@})\).  Now we can "bend" it with the absolute value function as follows:

\[ {@abs(x)*(x-2*n)@}\]

This is plotted below. {@plot(abs(x)*(x-2*n),[x,-2,2*(n+1)])@}

falsefeedback.text: Your answer does not have a stationary point at \(x={@n@}\) but should do.
Your answer fails to be continuous at \(x=0\) but should be.
Your answer is differentiable at \(x=0\) but should not be!  You were asked for a non-differentiable function at \(x=0\).  Consider using \(|x|\), which is entered as abs(x) somewhere in your answer.

questiontext.text:
Consider the real function

\[ f(x) :=\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} {@f0@} & \mbox{for } x\leq {@x0@}, \\ p(x) & \mbox{for } {@x0@} < x < {@x1@}, \\ {@f1@} & \mbox{for } {@x1@}\leq x.\end{array} \right. \]

{@plot(pg,[x,(x0-2),(x1+5)],[y,-3,3])@}

Find the cubic polynomial \(p(x)\) which makes \(f(x)\) continuously differentiable. 

\(p(x)=\)[[input:ans1]]

[[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
First we need to find the information which \(p(x)\) needs to satisfy.  This is

\[ p({@x0@})={@subst(x=x0,f0)@}.\]

\[ p({@x1@})={@subst(x=x1,f1)@}.\]

\[ p'({@x0@})={@subst(x=x0,diff(f0,x))@}.\]

\[ p'({@x1@})={@subst(x=x1,diff(f1,x))@}.\]

If we define \(p(x)\) to be the cubic 

\[ p(x) = a_3 x^3 + a_2 x^2 + a_1 x + a_0,\]

We then set up the matrix equation

\[ {@CS@} {@CV@} = {@CT@} \]

Solving this gives the coefficients, from which we get the polynomial.

{@ta@}.

We can view this as {@plot([pg,tapt],[x,(x0-3),(x1+3)],[y,-3,3])@}

feedbackvariables.text: anspt : if (x>x0 and x<x1) then ans1 else 1000;

falsefeedback.text: Your answer does not satisfy \({@p(x0)=subst(x=x0,f0)@}\).
Your answer does not satisfy \({@p(x1)=subst(x=x1,f1)@}\).
Your answer does not satisfy \(p'({@x0@})={@subst(x=x0,diff(f0,x))@}\).
Your answer does not satisfy \(p'({@x1@})={@subst(x=x1,diff(f1,x))@}\).
Your answer is not a cubic!

Your answer is plotted below, although part of your graph might appear out of range of the plot!

{@plot([pg,anspt],[x,(x0-2),(x1+5)],[y,-3,3])@}

questiontext.text:
For what value of \(k\) is \[ {@A@} {@B@}={@B@} {@A@},\] i.e. \(AB=BA\)?

\(k=\)[[input:ans]] [[validation:ans]]

generalfeedback.text:
The product
\[ AB = {@A@} {@B@} = {@A.B@}\]
The product
\[ BA = {@B@} {@A@} = {@B.A@}\]
From this we see that
\[ {@AB[2,1]@} = {@BA[2,1]@}\]
and
\[ {@AB[1,2]@} = {@BA[1,2]@}.\]
Fortunately, when solved these give the same solution \(k={@d@}\).

falsefeedback.text: For your value of \(k={@ans@}\) you have \[ {@A@}{@matrix([a,b],[c,ans])@} = {@A.matrix([a,b],[c,ans])@} \] \[ {@matrix([a,b],[c,ans])@}{@A@} = {@matrix([a,b],[c,ans]).A@} \]

name.text: Find the expression of the tangent line

questiontext.text:
Consider the function \({\displaystyle f(x) = {@g(x) + d1@}}\) whose graph is displayed below.

The tangent line through the point \(({@x0@}, {@y0@})\) is also a function. Determine its expression.

You can use the GeoGebra applet below to move the secant line into a tangent line by moving the points A and B. There are other ways to solve this problem.

What is the slope of the tangent line at the pont \(({@x0@}, {@y0@})\)?
By slope we mean the ratio of the \(y\)- and \(x\)-coordinate changes of the line.
Answer: [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:ans1]]

At which point does the tangent line cross the \(y\)-axis?
Give only the value of the \(y\)-coordinate.
Answer: [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:ans2]]

Formulate the expression of the tangent line by using the formula \(g(x) = kx + b\), where \(k\) is the slope and \(b\) is the point where the line crosses the \(y\)-axis.
Answer: Tangent line's function is \(g(x)\) = [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:ans3]].

This is a Java Applet created using GeoGebra from www.geogebra.org - it looks like you don't have Java installed, please go to www.java.com

This web page requires Java and it does not work in Google Chrome browser (version 13).

generalfeedback.text:
Reading from the applet we see that the slope of the tangent line is {@slope@}.
The tangent line crosses the \(y\)-axis at the point {@y2@}.
Hence, its function on \(x\) is \(g(x) = {@slopefn@}\).

questionnote.text:
Reading from the applet we see that the slope of the tangent line is {@slope@}.
The tangent line crosses the \(y\)-axis at the point {@y2@}.
Hence, its function on \(x\) is \(f(x) = {@slopefn@}\).

questiontext.text:
Calculate \[ {@A@}.{@B@}\]

 [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
To multiply matrices \(A\) and \(B\) we need to remember that the \((i,j)\)th entry is the scalar product of the \(i\)th row of \(A\) with the \(j\)th column of \(B\).

\[ {@A@}.{@B@} = {@C@} = {@D@}.\]

truefeedback.text: Remember, you don't multiply matrices by multiplying the corresponding entries! A quite different process is needed.
Please multiply the matrices. It looks like you have added them instead!

questiontext.text:
Write the following in partial fractions. \[{@p@}\]

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

Integrate your expression with respect to \(x\).

[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

Find

\[ \int_{0}^{1} {@p@} \mathrm{d}x.\]

[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
Writing {@p@} in partial fractions we have
\[ {@p1@}\]
Integrating this with respect to \(x\) gives
\[ {@p2@}+c\]
so that
\[ \int_{0}^{1} {@p@}, \mathrm{d}x = {@p3@}.\]

falsefeedback.text: You must complete part 2 before trying this part.
Your answer is correct.  Please fully simplify your answer and write it in traditional form.

questiontext.text:
1. Give an example of an odd function by typing an expression which represents it. \(f_1(x)=\) [[input:ans1]]. [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:odd]]

2. Give an example of an even function. \(f_2(x)=\) [[input:ans2]]. [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:even]]

3. Give an example of a function which is odd and even. \(f_3(x)=\) [[input:ans3]]. [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:oddeven]]

4. Is the answer to 3. unique? [[input:ans4]] (Or are there many different possibilities.) [[validation:ans4]] [[feedback:unique]]

falsefeedback.text: Your answer is not an even function. Look, \[ f(x)-f(-x)={@sa@} \neq 0.\]
Your answer is not an odd function. Look, \[ f(x)+f(-x)={@sa@} \neq 0.\]
Your answer is not an odd function. Look, \[ f(x)+f(-x)={@sa1@} \neq 0.\]
Your answer is not an even function. Look, \[ f(x)-f(-x)={@sa2@} \neq 0.\]

questiontext.text: Find the general solution to \[ {@q@} =0 \] [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

falsefeedback.text: Your answer should satisfy the differential equation, but in fact when we substitute your expression into the differential equation we get \[{@p@}\] which is not zero, so you must have done something wrong.
You should have a general solution, which includes unknown constants. Your answer satisfies the differential equation, but does not have the correct number of unknown constants.

truefeedback.text: Your general solution should be a sum of two linearly independent components, but is not.

questiontext.text: Find the general solution to \[ {@q@} =0 \] [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

falsefeedback.text: Your answer should satisfy the differential equation, but in fact when we substitute your expression into the differential equation we get \[{@p@}\] which is not zero, so you must have done something wrong.
You should have a general solution, which includes unknown constants. Your answer satisfies the differential equation, but does not have the correct number of unknown constants.

truefeedback.text: Your general solution should be a sum of two linearly independent components, but is not.

questiontext.text: Find the solution to \[ {@q@} =0 \] subject to \[ y(0) = {@y0@} \] and \[ y'(0) = {@y1@} \] [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

falsefeedback.text: Your answer should satisfy the differential equation, but in fact when we substitute your expression into the differential equation we get \[{@p@}\] which is not zero, so you must have done something wrong.
Your answer should satisfy \[ y(0) = {@y0@} \] but does not. When we substitute \(t=0\) in your answer we get {@b0@} instead.
Your answer should satisfy \[ y'(0) = {@y1@} \] but does not. When we substitute \(t=0\) into the derivative of your answer we get {@b1@} instead.

questiontext.text:
In a railway journey of \(90km\) an increase of \(5\) kilometers per hour in the speed decreases the time taken by \(15\) minutes.

Write a system of equations (one equation per line) to represent this situation using \(v\) as the speed of the train and \(t\) as the time.
[[input:asys]] [[validation:asys]] [[feedback:prt1]]

Eliminate \(t\) from your equations, writing a single equation only in \(v\) which represents this situation.
[[input:veqn]] [[validation:veqn]] [[feedback:prt2]]

What is the velocity? [[input:ansv]] [[validation:ansv]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
Let \(v\) be thespeed of the train, \(d\) the distance travelled and \(t\) time. If \(t\) is the time (in hours) then \(15\) minutes is \(1/4\) hour.

We need to use the equation \(d=v\times t\) twice.

For the original journey we have \[ 90 = v\times t.\] For the faster journey we have \[ 90 = (v+5)(t-1/4).\]

truefeedback.text: Please check your time units very carefully!

name.text: tangent to a random polynomial at a point

questiontext.text:
Find the equation of the line tangent to \(p(x):=\){@p@} at the point \(x={@pt@}\).

1. Differentiate {@p@} with respect to \(x\). [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

2. Evaluate your derivative at \(x={@pt@}\). [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

3. Hence, find the equation of the tangent line to \(p\) at \(x={@pt@}\). \(y=\)[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. The derivative of {@p@} with respect to \(x\) is \[ {@ta1@}.\]

2. If we subsitiute \(x={@pt@}\) into \(p'(x)\) we have \(p'({@pt@})={@ta2@}\).

3. The tangent line is given by the equation

\[ y = m(x-a)+c\]

where \(m\) is the gradient of the line, \(a\) is the point at which the tangent line is being contructed and \(c:=p(a)\).  In our case we have \(a={@pt@}\), \(m={@ta2@}\) and \(c=p({@pt@})={@c@}\).  Combining these we have

\[ y={@ta2*(x-pt)+c@} = {@ta3@}.\]

questionvariables.text: p : (2+rand(3))*x^3+(3+rand(3))*x^2+(2+rand(3))*x pt:2 c:subst(x=pt,p) ta1:diff(p,x) ta2:subst(x=pt,diff(p,x)) ta3:remainder(p,(x-pt)^2)

falsefeedback.text: Your answer to this part is correct, however you have got part 1 wrong! Please try both parts again!

questiontext.text: Find \[ \int {@p@} d{@v@}\] [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text: We can either do this question by inspection (i.e. spot the answer) or in a more formal manner by using the substitution \[ u = ({@v@}-{@a@}).\] Then, since \(\frac{d}{d{@v@}}u=1\) we have \[ \int {@p@} d{@v@} = \int u^{@n@} du = \frac{u^{@n+1@}}{{@n+1@}}+c = {@ta@}+c.\]

questiontext.text:
A rectangle has length {@sg@}cm greater than its width. If it has an area of \({@abs(ar)@}cm^2\), find the dimensions of the rectangle.

1. Write down an equation which relates the side lengths to the area of the rectangle.
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:eq]]

2. Solve your equation. Enter your answer as a set of numbers.
[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:sol]]

3. Hence, find the length of the shorter side.
[[input:ans3]] cm [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:short]]

generalfeedback.text: If \(x\)cm is the width then \((x+{@sg@})\) is the length. Now the area is \({@abs(ar)@}cm^2\) and so \[ {@x*(x+sg)=-ar@}.\] \[ {@x^2+sg*x+ar@}=0\] \[ {@(x+rp)*(x+rn)=0@} \] So that \(x={@-rp@}\) or \(x={@-rn@}\). Since lengths are positive quantities \(x>0\) and we discard the negative root. Hence the length of the shorter side is \(x={@-rn@}\)cm.

truefeedback.text: You have correctly solved the equation you have entered in part 1. Please try both parts again!
